reviewText: I don't think there has been any actual reviews from someone with a vr device, so I'll say that this game is neat. It's free and  only like 200mb download. It feels very natural and intuitive to pick up stuff. Physics is kinda ♥♥♥♥ed up but it doesn't really matter, it's a free game.\n\nTo expand more on this, you basically start out immediately as the medic from tf2 in the operating room. There is no tutorial on controls or what to do at all. At first this may seem confusing, but the controls are so damn intuitive that it doesn't matter. You can really naturally pick things up, press buttons, and it feels great. It also runs really well and maintains 90fps even on my old graphics card. So this is definitely a good showcase of the hand controls and runs well too.

reviewText:
If you start the game and are staring at an empty black room, there is a glowing circle right behind you that you need to stick your hand in to start the operation. I don't know what they were thinking.

Surgeon Simulator was designed to be played with incredibly clunky keyboard and mouse controls - much of the charm was in the fact that it was so difficult to do anything, that you'd screw up everything in a highly entertaining fashion. Getting the operations right required extreme precision and lots of practice.

The VR version seems like a natural step, and it's definitely entertaining, but it's simply far too easy when you have full natural control over your hand(s). I beat this operation on my first try in less than three minutes, where it would have taken me a good 10-15 minutes with the original version. Even though it's free, it's hard to justify such a large download for 3 minutes of gameplay. If you haven't played SS before, you'll probably get more play time out of it - but this version doesn't have a menu or explain how to do anything and you might be very confused.

Essentially all you need to do is remove the ribcage and internal organs without making the Heavy bleed too much. If he runs out of blood, he dies and you lose. You can see how much blood is left in the elevated jar behind him. Once you have removed the organs, well... watch the Meet the Medic" promo video to understand the rest of the operation.

As with the original game
date: the worst thing about this level is the ♥♥♥♥ing joystick that controls the ♥♥♥♥ing medic gun. Its axes aren't aligned with the medic gun itself so the medic gun doesn't move how you would expect when you move the joystick. I recommend getting the medic gun pointed at the Heavy's chest before you do anything else - if you save it for the last step
recommended: you'll never get it pointed at him before he bleeds out."

reviewText: This is basically just a VR port of the slightly hidden Meet the Medic surgery from Surgeon Simulator. It's considerably easier when you're able to not only control your hand with your hand but also use both hands instead of just one, but it's still fun to play around with and there are some extra features added in like the ability to see your head and hands in the mirror in the form of the Medic's. It's fun, it's free, and it's a good short experience to show your friends.

reviewText:
A nice VR demo for any TF2 fan. I'd recommend it for anyone with a Vive, even though your not missing much if you choose not to play it.

Pros:
Graphics are what you'd expect to see in TF2, which helps convince you you're in the world.
Lots of melee weapons from TF2. You can use the Scout's bat, the Spy's knife, and more!
Even though it was short, it was very immersive since you're focusing on the surgery, taking out the heart, moving stuff around, etc.
The controls are a bit derpy, but I'm counting this as a pro because that's the style of Surgeon Simulator. It's not really meant to be taken seriously.
It's free. The only thing it costs you is hard drive space.


Cons:
You need to know what happens in the Meet the Medic" TF2 short in order to complete the surgery.
It's not EXACTLY like the "Meet the Medic" video
date: but it's very close. For instance
recommended: the heart doesn't get ubered at any point
hoursPlayed:
and the Heavy is never awake (which would be beyond creepy anyway).
It's short (it's pretty much a demo after all). If you speed run it you can finish it in under a minute.
Very little replay value (because it's more of a demo). It's only one surgery. You can do everything in the game within 5 minutes.
If you look in the mirror
voteText:
you'll see yourself as a floating medic head and gloves. This can break your immersion while being creepy at the same time.

In conclusion:
It's free. If you've got the Vive
helpfulPercent: there's really no reason to not download this game and give it a try. If you choose to not download it
votesTotal: but there really aren't any reasons to skip this demo."

reviewText:
Product received for free

You paradoxically lose some of the charm in VR as six DOF tracked motion controllers are too good. With a mouse and keyboard, it was a challenge and random mistakes/absurd outcomes was the norm.

It's still an interesting experience and for free it's hard to complain.

Also heavys arms are the size of f-ing tree trunks.

reviewText:
Really fun, I can see a full VR surgeon simulator being a fun game, although currently in the demo there are some issues with clipping. (I get that the game is clunky, it's more of the rogue tracking that seems to occur during clips that cause issues.)

Overall, it's a good demo though, although one note is that people not using roomscale will probably have issues. The game provides you no way of moving yourself around at the moment so even though it isn't listed as a 'roomscale required' title, if you don't have some extra space to move around you may want to skip this for now.

Another thing is that this is one of the few VR game's I've bumped into where performance has been a bit of an issue. Not massive, but frame stutters were common at times.

For reference;
Latest drivers/chipsets installed as of posting this.
CPU - FX8350
GPU - GTX 980 4GB
Memory - 16GB RAM
